title: 103_hr822
content: The Act titled "Middle Class Flexible Savings Act of 1993" increases the maximum IRA deduction and income phaseout limits, with adjustments for inflation. The Act "Middle Class Flexible Savings Act of 1993" raises the maximum IRA deduction to $3,000 and income phaseout limits to $50,000, with adjustments for inflation. The Act "Middle Class Flexible Savings Act of 1993" increases the maximum IRA deduction to $12,000 and adjusts income phaseout limits for inflation. The applicable dollar amount for various sections ranges from $3,000 to $50,000, with rounding rules specified for amounts not multiples of $50. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 1992. SEC. 3. IRA for nonworking spouse with young children based on both spouses' compensation. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code allows a higher deduction limit for a qualifying spouse with young children, capped at $3,000 or the sum of their and their spouse's gross income. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code allows a higher deduction limit for a qualifying spouse with young children, capped at $3,000 or the sum of their and their spouse's gross income. A qualifying spouse is defined as any spouse of an individual who files a joint return, has less than $1,000 of compensation, and has a child who has not attained age. The amendment made by this section applies to taxable years beginning after December 31, 1992 for a dependent child under age 6. Penalty-free withdrawals allowed from certain plans for educational, medical, and business start-up expenses. Penalty-free withdrawals permitted from specific plans for educational and business start-up expenses under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Penalty-free withdrawals allowed from certain plans for education and business start-up expenses under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, subject to limits on distributions based on qualified higher education expenses and start-up expenditures. Adjusted gross income of the distributee must not exceed a certain limit for distributions from an individual retirement plan. Penalty-free withdrawals are permitted from specific plans for education and business start-up expenses under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The adjusted gross income limit for distributions from an individual retirement plan is set at $60,000 for unmarried individuals, $70,000 for joint returns, and $35,000 for married individuals filing separately. Qualified higher education expenses include tuition, fees, books, supplies, and equipment necessary for enrollment or attendance. The text discusses the attendance of the taxpayer, spouse, or child at an eligible educational institution and the coordination with savings bond provisions. It also mentions the amendment to exceptions for penalty-free withdrawals from individual retirement plans for catastrophic illness expenses. The text discusses exceptions for penalty-free withdrawals from individual retirement plans for medical expenses, based on adjusted gross income limitations. The text introduces amendments to sections 401(k)(2)(B)(i) and 403(b)(11) of the Internal Revenue Code regarding distributions for qualified higher education expenses and start-up expenses. The text introduces amendments for the payment of qualified higher education expenses or start-up expenses. The effective date for these amendments applies to payments and distributions after the enactment of this Act.
